column1: == History ==
It is a testimony to the sanctity of the location in the mindset of followers of medieval Norse religion that Gamla Uppsala was the last stronghold of pre-Christian
column2: Norse Germanic kingship. During the 1070s and 1080 there appears to have been a renaissance of Norse religion with the magnificent Temple at Uppsala described in a contested account through an eye-witness by Adam of Bremen. Adam of Bremen relates of the Uppsala of the 1070s and describes it as a pagan cult centre with the enormous Temple at Uppsala containing wooden statues of Odin
column3: Thor and Freyr.

column1: Sometime in the 1080s the Christian king Ingi was exiled for refusing to perform the sacrifices. Instead Blot-Sweyn was elected
column2: but he was killed by Ingi who could then reclaim his throne.

column1: == The Royal Mounds ==
The Royal Mounds (Swedish: Kungshögarna) is the name of the three large barrows located in Gamla Uppsala. According to ancient mythology and folklore
column2: the three gods Thor
column3: Oden and Freyr would be at rest in Kungshögarna or Uppsala högar (from the Old Norse word Haugr meaning mound or barrow; cognate English Howe). In the 19th and 20th centuries

The excavation was complex and generated a lot of publicity. A 25-metre-long (82 ft) tunnel was dug into the mound

column1: == Gamla Uppsala Church ==
Gamla Uppsala Church (Gamla Uppsala kyrka) was the Archbishopric of Sweden prior to 1273
column2: when the archbishopric was moved to Östra Aros (Östra Aros was then renamed Uppsala due to a papal request). The old cathedral was probably built in the 11th century
column3: but finished in the 12th century. The stone building may have been preceded by a wooden church and probably by the large Temple at Uppsala. After a fire in 1240
column4: the nave and transepts of the cathedral were removed
column5: leaving only the choir and central tower
column6: and with the addition of the sacristy and the porch gave the church its present outer appearance. In the 15th century
column7: vaults were added as well as chalk paintings. Among the medieval wooden sculptures there are three crucifixes from the 12th
column8: 13th and 15th centuries. Archbishop Valerius  was buried here. King Eric IX of Sweden was as well
column9: before being moved to Uppsala Cathedral. Astronomer
column10: physicist and mathematician Anders Celsius (1701–1744) was also buried at Gamla Uppsala Church next to his grandfather Magnus Celsius (1621–1679).
